<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Carbon_dioxide skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Carbon dioxide</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-vandalism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-vandalism (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-vandalism</a>
</p>
<div class="dablink">"Co2" redirects here. For the sporadic group, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Conway_group_Co2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Conway group Co2 (page does not exist)">Conway group Co2</a>.</div><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chembox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chembox (page does not exist)">Template:Chembox</a>
<b>Carbon dioxide</b> (<a href="/wiki/Chemical_formula" title="Chemical formula">chemical formula</a> <b>CO<sub>2</sub></b>) is a naturally occurring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chemical_compound&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chemical compound (page does not exist)">chemical compound</a> composed of 2 <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">oxygen</a> <a href="/wiki/Atom" title="Atom">atoms</a> each <a href="/wiki/Covalent_bond" title="Covalent bond">covalently</a> <a href="/wiki/Double_bond" title="Double bond">double bonded</a> to a single <a href="/wiki/Carbon" title="Carbon">carbon</a> atom. It is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gas (page does not exist)">gas</a> at <a href="/wiki/Standard_temperature_and_pressure" title="Standard temperature and pressure" class="mw-redirect">standard temperature and pressure</a> and exists in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Earth%27s_atmosphere&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Earth's atmosphere (page does not exist)">Earth's atmosphere</a> in this state, as a <a href="/wiki/Trace_gas" title="Trace gas">trace gas</a> at a concentration of 0.039 per cent by volume.<sup id="cite_ref-NOAA_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA-1">[1]</a></sup>
</p><p>As part of the <a href="/wiki/Carbon_cycle" title="Carbon cycle">carbon cycle</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plant (page does not exist)">plants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">algae</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cyanobacteria" title="Cyanobacteria">cyanobacteria</a> use <a href="/wiki/Light" title="Light">light</a> <a href="/wiki/Energy" title="Energy">energy</a> to <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis">photosynthesize</a> <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrate</a> from carbon dioxide and <a href="/wiki/Water" title="Water">water</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">oxygen</a> produced as a waste product.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> However, photosynthesis cannot occur in darkness and at night some carbon dioxide is produced by plants during <a href="/wiki/Cellular_respiration" title="Cellular respiration">respiration</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Carbon dioxide is produced by <a href="/wiki/Combustion" title="Combustion">combustion</a> of coal or <a href="/wiki/Hydrocarbon" title="Hydrocarbon">hydrocarbons</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (page does not exist)">fermentation</a> of sugars in <a href="/wiki/Beer" title="Beer">beer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wine" title="Wine">winemaking</a> and by respiration of all living organisms. It is exhaled in the breath of humans and other land animals. It is emitted from <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcanoes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hot_spring" title="Hot spring">hot springs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Geyser" title="Geyser">geysers</a> and other places where the earth's crust is thin and is freed from <a href="/wiki/Carbonate_rock" title="Carbonate rock">carbonate rocks</a> by <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_(chemistry)" title="Dissolution (chemistry)">dissolution</a>. CO<sub>2</sub> is also found in lakes, at depth under the sea and commingled with oil and gas deposits.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>The environmental effects of carbon dioxide are of significant interest. Atmospheric carbon dioxide is the primary source of carbon in <a href="/wiki/Life" title="Life">life</a> on Earth and its concentration in Earth's pre-industrial atmosphere since late in the <a href="/wiki/Precambrian" title="Precambrian">Precambrian</a> eon was regulated by <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis">photosynthetic</a> organisms. Carbon dioxide is an important <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas</a>; burning of carbon-based fuels since the industrial revolution has rapidly increased the concentration, leading to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming (page does not exist)">global warming</a>. It is also a major source of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ocean_acidification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ocean acidification (page does not exist)">ocean acidification</a> since it dissolves in water to form <a href="/wiki/Carbonic_acid" title="Carbonic acid">carbonic acid</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> which is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Acid_strength&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Acid strength (page does not exist)">weak acid</a> as its ionization in water is incomplete.
</p>
<dl>
<dd> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> + <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Eqm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Eqm (page does not exist)">Template:Eqm</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>
</dd>
</dl>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Carbon-dioxide-crystal-3D-vdW.png" title="File:Carbon-dioxide-crystal-3D-vdW.png">File:Carbon-dioxide-crystal-3D-vdW.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Crystal structure of <a href="/wiki/Dry_ice" title="Dry ice">dry ice</a></div></div></div>
<p>Carbon dioxide was one of the first gases to be described as a substance distinct from air. In the seventeenth century, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flemish_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flemish people (page does not exist)">Flemish</a> chemist <a href="/wiki/Jan_Baptist_van_Helmont" title="Jan Baptist van Helmont">Jan Baptist van Helmont</a> observed that when he burned <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charcoal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charcoal (page does not exist)">charcoal</a> in a closed vessel, the mass of the resulting <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ash_(analytical_chemistry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ash (analytical chemistry) (page does not exist)">ash</a> was much less than that of the original charcoal. His interpretation was that the rest of the charcoal had been transmuted into an invisible substance he termed a "gas" or "wild spirit" (<i>spiritus sylvestre</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>The properties of carbon dioxide were studied more thoroughly in the 1750s by the <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> physician <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Black" title="Joseph Black">Joseph Black</a>. He found that <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a> (<a href="/wiki/Calcium_carbonate" title="Calcium carbonate">calcium carbonate</a>) could be heated or treated with <a href="/wiki/Acid" title="Acid">acids</a> to yield a gas he called "fixed air." He observed that the fixed air was denser than air and supported neither flame nor animal life. Black also found that when bubbled through an aqueous solution of lime (<a href="/wiki/Calcium_hydroxide" title="Calcium hydroxide">calcium hydroxide</a>), it would <a href="/wiki/Precipitation_(chemistry)" title="Precipitation (chemistry)">precipitate</a> calcium carbonate. He used this phenomenon to illustrate that carbon dioxide is produced by animal respiration and microbial fermentation. In 1772, English chemist <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Priestley" title="Joseph Priestley">Joseph Priestley</a> published a paper entitled <i>Impregnating Water with Fixed Air</i> in which he described a process of dripping <a href="/wiki/Sulfuric_acid" title="Sulfuric acid">sulfuric acid</a> (or <i>oil of vitriol</i> as Priestley knew it) on chalk in order to produce carbon dioxide, and forcing the gas to dissolve by agitating a bowl of water in contact with the gas.<sup id="cite_ref-Priestley_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Priestley-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p><p>Carbon dioxide was first liquefied (at elevated pressures) in 1823 by <a href="/wiki/Humphry_Davy" title="Humphry Davy">Humphry Davy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Michael_Faraday" title="Michael Faraday">Michael Faraday</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Davy_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davy-8">[8]</a></sup> The earliest description of solid carbon dioxide was given by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adrien-Jean-Pierre_Thilorier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adrien-Jean-Pierre Thilorier (page does not exist)">Adrien-Jean-Pierre Thilorier</a>, who in 1835 opened a pressurized container of liquid carbon dioxide, only to find that the cooling produced by the rapid evaporation of the liquid yielded a "snow" of solid CO<sub>2</sub>.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Chemical_and_physical_properties">Chemical and physical properties</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Structure_and_bonding">Structure and bonding</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The carbon dioxide molecule is linear and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Centrosymmetric&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Centrosymmetric (page does not exist)">centrosymmetric</a>. The two C=O bonds are equivalent and are short (116.3 <a href="/wiki/Picometer" title="Picometer" class="mw-redirect">pm</a>), consistent with double bonding.<sup id="cite_ref-Green_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Green-10">[10]</a></sup>  Since it is centrosymmetric, the molecule has no electrical <a href="/wiki/Dipole" title="Dipole">dipole</a>. Consistent with this fact, only two vibrational bands are observed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=IR_spectrum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IR spectrum (page does not exist)">IR spectrum</a> – an antisymmetic stretching mode at 2349&#160;cm<sup>−1</sup> and a bending mode near 666&#160;cm<sup>−1</sup>. There is also a symmetric stretching mode at 1388&#160;cm<sup>−1</sup> which is only observed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raman_spectrum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raman spectrum (page does not exist)">Raman spectrum</a>.
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><a href="/wiki/File:Co2comp.png" title="File:Co2comp.png">350px</a></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_aqueous_solution">In aqueous solution</span></h3>
<p>Carbon dioxide is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soluble&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soluble (page does not exist)">soluble</a> in water, in which it reversibly converts to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> (<a href="/wiki/Carbonic_acid" title="Carbonic acid">carbonic acid</a>).
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Henry%27s_law" title="Henry's law">hydration equilibrium constant</a> of carbonic acid is &lt;math&gt;K_{\mathrm h}=\frac{\rm{[H_2CO_3]}}{\rm{[CO_2(aq)]}}=1.70\times 10^{-3}&lt;/math&gt; (at 25 °C). Hence, the majority of the carbon dioxide is not converted into carbonic acid, but remains as CO<sub>2</sub> molecules not affecting the pH.
</p><p>The relative concentrations of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Deprotonation" title="Deprotonation">deprotonated</a> forms <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> (<a href="/wiki/Bicarbonate" title="Bicarbonate">bicarbonate</a>) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>(<a href="/wiki/Carbonate" title="Carbonate">carbonate</a>) depend on the <a href="/wiki/PH" title="PH">pH</a>. As shown in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bjerrum_plot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bjerrum plot (page does not exist)">Bjerrum plot</a>, in neutral or slightly alkaline water (pH &gt; 6.5), the bicarbonate form predominates (&gt;50%) becoming the most prevalent (&gt;95%) at the pH of seawater. In very alkaline water (pH &gt; 10.4), the predominant (&gt;50%) form is carbonate. The oceans, being mildly alkaline with typical pH = 8.2–8.5, contain about 120&#160;mg of bicarbonate per liter.
</p><p>Being <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diprotic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diprotic acid (page does not exist)">diprotic</a>, carbonic acid has two <a href="/wiki/Acid_dissociation_constant" title="Acid dissociation constant">acid dissociation constants</a>, the first one for the dissociation into the <a href="/wiki/Bicarbonate" title="Bicarbonate">bicarbonate</a> (also called hydrogen carbonate) ion (HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>):
</p>
<dl>
<dd>H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Eqm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Eqm (page does not exist)">Template:Eqm</a> HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> + H<sup>+</sup>
</dd>
<dd><i>K</i><sub>a1</sub> = <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Val&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Val (page does not exist)">Template:Val</a>; p<i>K</i><sub>a1</sub> = 3.6 at 25 °C.<sup id="cite_ref-Green_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Green-10">[10]</a></sup>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>This is the <i>true</i> first acid dissociation constant, defined as &lt;math&gt;K_{a1}=\frac{\rm{[HCO_3^-] [H^+]}}{\rm{[H_2CO_3]}}&lt;/math&gt;, where the denominator includes only covalently bound H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and excludes hydrated CO<sub>2</sub>(aq). The much smaller and often-quoted value near <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Val&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Val (page does not exist)">Template:Val</a> is an <i>apparent</i> value calculated on the (incorrect) assumption that all dissolved CO<sub>2</sub> is present as carbonic acid, so that &lt;math&gt;K_{\mathrm{a1}}{\rm{(apparent)}}=\frac{\rm{[HCO_3^-] [H^+]}}{\rm{[H_2CO_3] + [CO_2(aq)]}}&lt;/math&gt;. Since most of the dissolved CO<sub>2</sub> remains as CO<sub>2</sub> molecules, <i>K</i><sub>a1</sub>(apparent) has a much larger denominator and a much smaller value than the true <i>K</i><sub>a1</sub>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Bicarbonate" title="Bicarbonate">bicarbonate</a> ion is an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amphoteric&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amphoteric (page does not exist)">amphoteric</a> species that can act as an acid or as a base, depending on pH of the solution. At high <a href="/wiki/PH" title="PH">pH</a>, it dissociates significantly into the <a href="/wiki/Carbonate" title="Carbonate">carbonate</a> ion (CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup>):
</p>
<dl>
<dd>HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Eqm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Eqm (page does not exist)">Template:Eqm</a> CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup> + H<sup>+</sup>
</dd>
<dd><i>K</i><sub>a2</sub> = <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Val&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Val (page does not exist)">Template:Val</a>; p<i>K</i><sub>a2</sub> = 10.329
</dd>
</dl>
<p>In organisms carbonic acid production is catalysed by the <a href="/wiki/Enzyme" title="Enzyme">enzyme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carbonic_anhydrase" title="Carbonic anhydrase">carbonic anhydrase</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Chemical_reactions_of_CO2">Chemical reactions of CO<sub>2</sub></span></h3>
<p>CO<sub>2</sub> is a weak <a href="/wiki/Electrophile" title="Electrophile">electrophile</a>. Its reaction with basic water illustrates this property, in which case <a href="/wiki/Hydroxide" title="Hydroxide">hydroxide</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Nucleophile" title="Nucleophile">nucleophile</a>. Other nucleophiles react as well. For example, <a href="/wiki/Carbanion" title="Carbanion">carbanions</a> as provided by  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grignard_reagent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grignard reagent (page does not exist)">Grignard reagents</a> and <a href="/wiki/Organolithium_compound" title="Organolithium compound" class="mw-redirect">organolithium compounds</a> react with CO<sub>2</sub> to give carboxylates:
</p>
<dl>
<dd>MR  +  CO<sub>2</sub>   →   RCO<sub>2</sub>M   (where M = Li or MgBr and R = <a href="/wiki/Alkyl" title="Alkyl">alkyl</a> or <a href="/wiki/Aryl" title="Aryl">aryl</a>).
</dd>
</dl>
<p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metal_carbon_dioxide_complex&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metal carbon dioxide complex (page does not exist)">metal carbon dioxide complexes</a>, CO<sub>2</sub> serves as a ligand, which can facilitate the conversion of CO<sub>2</sub> to other chemicals.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>The reduction of CO<sub>2</sub> to CO is ordinarily a difficult and slow reaction:
</p>
<dl>
<dd>CO<sub>2</sub> +  2 e<sup>−</sup>  +  2H<sup>+</sup>   →   CO  +  H<sub>2</sub>O
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The redox potential for this reaction near pH 7 is about −0.53 V <i>versus</i> the <a href="/wiki/Standard_hydrogen_electrode" title="Standard hydrogen electrode">standard hydrogen electrode</a>. The nickel-containing enzyme <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbon_monoxide_dehydrogenase&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbon monoxide dehydrogenase (page does not exist)">carbon monoxide dehydrogenase</a> catalyses this process.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Physical_properties">Physical properties</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Carbon_dioxide_pressure-temperature_phase_diagram.svg" title="File:Carbon dioxide pressure-temperature phase diagram.svg">File:Carbon dioxide pressure-temperature phase diagram.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Carbon dioxide pressure-temperature phase diagram showing the <a href="/wiki/Triple_point" title="Triple point">triple point</a> and <a href="/wiki/Critical_point_(thermodynamics)" title="Critical point (thermodynamics)">critical point</a> of carbon dioxide</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dry_Ice_Pellets_Subliming.jpg" title="File:Dry Ice Pellets Subliming.jpg">File:Dry Ice Pellets Subliming.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sample of solid carbon dioxide or "dry ice" pellets</div></div></div>
<p>Carbon dioxide is colorless. At low concentrations, the gas is odorless. At higher concentrations it has a sharp, acidic odor. At <a href="/wiki/Standard_conditions_for_temperature_and_pressure" title="Standard conditions for temperature and pressure">standard temperature and pressure</a>, the density of carbon dioxide is around 1.98&#160;kg/m<sup>3</sup>, about 1.67 times that of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Earth%27s_atmosphere&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Earth's atmosphere (page does not exist)">air</a>.
</p><p>Carbon dioxide has no liquid state at pressures below <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>. At 1 atmosphere (near mean sea level pressure), the gas <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deposition_(physics)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deposition (physics) (page does not exist)">deposits</a> directly to a solid at temperatures below <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and the solid <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sublimation_(chemistry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sublimation (chemistry) (page does not exist)">sublimes</a> directly to a gas above −78.5&#160;°C. In its solid state, carbon dioxide is commonly called <a href="/wiki/Dry_ice" title="Dry ice">dry ice</a>.
</p><p>Liquid carbon dioxide forms only at <a href="/wiki/Pressure" title="Pressure">pressures</a> above 5.1 atm; the <a href="/wiki/Triple_point" title="Triple point">triple point</a> of carbon dioxide is about 518 <a href="/wiki/KPa" title="KPa" class="mw-redirect">kPa</a> at −56.6&#160;°C (see phase diagram, above). The <a href="/wiki/Critical_point_(thermodynamics)" title="Critical point (thermodynamics)">critical point</a> is 7.38 MPa at 31.1&#160;°C.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Another form of solid carbon dioxide observed at high pressure is an <a href="/wiki/Amorphous" title="Amorphous" class="mw-redirect">amorphous</a> glass-like solid.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> This form of glass, called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Amorphous_carbonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amorphous carbonia (page does not exist)">carbonia</a></i>, is produced by <a href="/wiki/Supercooling" title="Supercooling">supercooling</a> heated CO<sub>2</sub> at extreme pressure (40–48 <a href="/w/index.php?title=GPa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="GPa (page does not exist)">GPa</a> or about 400,000 atmospheres) in a <a href="/wiki/Diamond_anvil" title="Diamond anvil" class="mw-redirect">diamond anvil</a>. This discovery confirmed the theory that carbon dioxide could exist in a glass state similar to other members of its elemental family, like <a href="/wiki/Silicon" title="Silicon">silicon</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Silica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Silica (page does not exist)">silica glass</a>) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Germanium_dioxide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Germanium dioxide (page does not exist)">germanium dioxide</a>. Unlike silica and germania glasses, however, carbonia glass is not stable at normal pressures and reverts to gas when pressure is released.
</p><p>At temperatures and pressures above the critical point, carbon dioxide behaves as a <a href="/wiki/Supercritical_fluid" title="Supercritical fluid">supercritical fluid</a> known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Supercritical_carbon_dioxide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Supercritical carbon dioxide (page does not exist)">supercritical carbon dioxide</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Isolation_and_production">Isolation and production</span></h2>
<p>Carbon dioxide is mainly produced as an unrecovered side product of four technologies: combustion of fossil fuels, production of hydrogen by steam reforming, ammonia synthesis, and fermentation. It can be obtained by or from air <a href="/wiki/Distillation" title="Distillation">distillation</a>, however, this method is inefficient.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Combustion" title="Combustion">combustion</a> of all carbon-containing fuels, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methane (page does not exist)">methane</a> (<a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a>), petroleum distillates (<a href="/wiki/Gasoline" title="Gasoline">gasoline</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diesel_fuel" title="Diesel fuel">diesel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kerosene" title="Kerosene">kerosene</a>, <a href="/wiki/Propane" title="Propane">propane</a>), but also of coal and wood, will yield carbon dioxide and, in most cases, water. As an example the chemical reaction between methane and oxygen is given below.
</p>
<dl>
<dd> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The production of <a href="/wiki/Quicklime" title="Quicklime" class="mw-redirect">quicklime</a> (CaO), a compound that enjoys widespread use, involves the heating (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Calcining&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Calcining (page does not exist)">calcining</a>) of limestone at about 850&#160;°C:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>
</dd>
</dl>
<p><a href="/wiki/Iron" title="Iron">Iron</a> is reduced from its oxides with <a href="/wiki/Coke_(fuel)" title="Coke (fuel)">coke</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Blast_furnace" title="Blast furnace">blast furnace</a>, producing <a href="/wiki/Pig_iron" title="Pig iron">pig iron</a> and carbon dioxide:<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<dl>
<dd> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>
</dd>
</dl>
<p><a href="/wiki/Yeast" title="Yeast">Yeast</a> metabolizes <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a> to produce carbon dioxide and <a href="/wiki/Ethanol" title="Ethanol">ethanol</a>, also known as alcohol, in the production of wines, beers and other spirits, but also in the production of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bioethanol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bioethanol (page does not exist)">bioethanol</a>:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> → <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>All <a href="/wiki/Cellular_respiration" title="Cellular respiration">aerobic</a> organisms produce <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> when they oxidize <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrates</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fatty_acid" title="Fatty acid">fatty acids</a>, and proteins in the mitochondria of cells. The large number of reactions involved are exceedingly complex and not described easily. Refer to (<a href="/wiki/Cellular_respiration" title="Cellular respiration">cellular respiration</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anaerobic_respiration" title="Anaerobic respiration">anaerobic respiration</a> and <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis">photosynthesis</a>). The equation for the respiration of glucose and other <a href="/wiki/Monosaccharide" title="Monosaccharide">monosachharides</a> is:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> + <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> → <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> + <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>
</dd>
</dl>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Photoautotrophs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Photoautotrophs (page does not exist)">Photoautotrophs</a> (i.e. plants, <a href="/wiki/Cyanobacteria" title="Cyanobacteria">cyanobacteria</a>) use another <i>modus operandi</i>: Plants absorb <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> from the air, and, together with water, react it to form carbohydrates:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> <i>n</i>CO<sub>2</sub> + <i>n</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>O → (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>)<sub>n</sub> + <i>n</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>
</dd>
</dl>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Laboratory_methods">Laboratory methods</span></h3>
<p>A variety of chemical routes to carbon dioxide are known, such as the reaction between most acids and most metal carbonates. For example, the reaction between <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hydrochloric_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hydrochloric acid (page does not exist)">hydrochloric acid</a> and calcium carbonate (limestone or chalk) is depicted below:
</p>
<dl>
<dd> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>
</dd>
</dl>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Carbonic_acid" title="Carbonic acid">carbonic acid</a> (H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) then decomposes to water and CO<sub>2</sub>. Such reactions are accompanied by foaming or bubbling, or both. In industry such reactions are widespread because they can be used to neutralize waste acid streams.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industrial_production">Industrial production</span></h3>
<p>Industrial carbon dioxide can be produced by several methods, many of which are practiced at various scales.<sup id="cite_ref-kirk_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kirk-17">[17]</a></sup>  In its dominant route, carbon dioxide is produced as a side product of the industrial production of <a href="/wiki/Ammonia" title="Ammonia">ammonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">hydrogen</a>. These processes begin with the reaction of water and natural gas (mainly methane).<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although carbon dioxide is not often recovered, carbon dioxide results from combustion of <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">fossil fuels</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wood" title="Wood">wood</a> as well  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(biochemistry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (biochemistry) (page does not exist)">fermentation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Brewing" title="Brewing">brewing</a> of <a href="/wiki/Beer" title="Beer">beer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Whisky" title="Whisky">whisky</a> and other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alcoholic_beverage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alcoholic beverage (page does not exist)">alcoholic beverages</a>. It also results from thermal decomposition of limestone, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>, in the manufacture of lime (<a href="/wiki/Calcium_oxide" title="Calcium oxide">calcium oxide</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>). It may be obtained directly from natural carbon dioxide <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spring_(hydrosphere)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spring (hydrosphere) (page does not exist)">springs</a>, where it is produced by the action of acidified water on <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a> or <a href="/wiki/Dolomite" title="Dolomite">dolomite</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Uses">Uses</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soda_bubbles_macro.jpg" title="File:Soda bubbles macro.jpg">File:Soda bubbles macro.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Carbon dioxide bubbles in a soft drink.</div></div></div>
<p>Carbon dioxide is used by the food industry, the oil industry, and the chemical industry.<sup id="cite_ref-kirk_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kirk-17">[17]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Precursor_to_chemicals">Precursor to chemicals</span></h3>
<p>In the chemical industry, carbon dioxide is mainly consumed as an ingredient in the production of <a href="/wiki/Urea" title="Urea">urea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Methanol" title="Methanol">methanol</a>. Metal <a href="/wiki/Carbonate" title="Carbonate">carbonates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bicarbonate" title="Bicarbonate">bicarbonates</a>, as well as some carboxylic acids derivatives (e.g., <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sodium_salicylate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sodium salicylate (page does not exist)">sodium salicylate</a>) are prepared from CO<sub>2</sub>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foods">Foods</span></h3>
<p>Carbon dioxide is a <a href="/wiki/Food_additive" title="Food additive">food additive</a> used as a propellant and acidity regulator in the food industry. It is approved for usage in the EU<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> (listed as <a href="/wiki/E_number" title="E number">E number</a> E290), USA<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> and Australia and New Zealand<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> (listed by its INS number 290).
</p><p>A candy called <a href="/wiki/Pop_Rocks" title="Pop Rocks">Pop Rocks</a> is pressurized with carbon dioxide gas at about 4 x 10<sup>6</sup> Pa (40 bar, 580 psi). When placed in the mouth, it dissolves (just like other hard candy) and releases the gas bubbles with an audible pop.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Leavening_agent" title="Leavening agent">Leavening agents</a> cause dough to rise by producing carbon dioxide. <a href="/wiki/Baker%27s_yeast" title="Baker's yeast">Baker's yeast</a> produces carbon dioxide by fermentation of sugars within the dough, while chemical leaveners such as <a href="/wiki/Baking_powder" title="Baking powder">baking powder</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baking_soda" title="Baking soda" class="mw-redirect">baking soda</a> release carbon dioxide when heated or if exposed to <a href="/wiki/Acid" title="Acid">acids</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Beverages">Beverages</span></h4>
<p>Carbon dioxide is used to produce <a href="/wiki/Carbonation" title="Carbonation">carbonated</a> <a href="/wiki/Soft_drink" title="Soft drink">soft drinks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soda_water" title="Soda water" class="mw-redirect">soda water</a>. Traditionally, the carbonation in beer and sparkling wine came about through natural fermentation, but many manufacturers carbonate these drinks with carbon dioxide recovered from the fermentation process. In the case of bottled and kegged beer, recycled carbon dioxide carbonation is the most common method used. With the exception of British <a href="/wiki/Real_Ale" title="Real Ale" class="mw-redirect">Real Ale</a>, draught beer is usually transferred from kegs in a cold room or cellar to dispensing taps on the bar using pressurized carbon dioxide, sometimes mixed with nitrogen.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Wine_making">Wine making</span></h4>
<p>Carbon dioxide in the form of <a href="/wiki/Dry_ice" title="Dry ice">dry ice</a> is often used in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wine_making&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wine making (page does not exist)">wine making</a> process to cool down bunches of <a href="/wiki/Grape" title="Grape">grapes</a> quickly after picking to help prevent spontaneous <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fermentation_(wine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fermentation (wine) (page does not exist)">fermentation</a> by wild <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yeast_(wine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yeast (wine) (page does not exist)">yeast</a>. The main advantage of using dry ice over regular water ice is that it cools the grapes without adding any additional water that may decrease the <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a> concentration in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grape_must&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grape must (page does not exist)">grape must</a>, and therefore also decrease the <a href="/wiki/Alcohol" title="Alcohol">alcohol</a> concentration in the finished wine.
</p><p>Dry ice is also used during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cold_soak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cold soak (page does not exist)">cold soak</a> phase of the wine making process to keep grapes cool. The carbon dioxide gas that results from the sublimation of the dry ice tends to settle to the bottom of tanks because it is denser than air. The settled carbon dioxide gas creates a hypoxic environment which helps to prevent bacteria from growing on the grapes until it is time to start the fermentation with the desired strain of yeast.
</p><p>Carbon dioxide is also used to create a hypoxic environment for <a href="/wiki/Carbonic_maceration" title="Carbonic maceration">carbonic maceration</a>, the process used to produce <a href="/wiki/Beaujolais" title="Beaujolais">Beaujolais</a> wine.
</p><p>Carbon dioxide is sometimes used to top up wine bottles or other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Storage_(wine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Storage (wine) (page does not exist)">storage</a> vessels such as barrels to prevent oxidation, though it has the problem that it can dissolve into the wine, making a previously still wine slightly fizzy. For this reason, other gases such as <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen" title="Nitrogen">nitrogen</a> or <a href="/wiki/Argon" title="Argon">argon</a> are preferred for this process by professional wine makers.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Inert_gas">Inert gas</span></h3>
<p>It is one of the most commonly used compressed gases for pneumatic (pressurized gas) systems in portable pressure tools. Carbon dioxide also finds use as an atmosphere for <a href="/wiki/Welding" title="Welding">welding</a>, although in the welding arc, it reacts to <a href="/wiki/Oxidation" title="Oxidation" class="mw-redirect">oxidize</a> most metals. Use in the automotive industry is common despite significant evidence that welds made in carbon dioxide are more <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brittle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brittle (page does not exist)">brittle</a> than those made in more inert atmospheres, and that such weld joints deteriorate over time because of the formation of carbonic acid. It is used as a welding gas primarily because it is much less expensive than more inert gases such as <a href="/wiki/Argon" title="Argon">argon</a> or <a href="/wiki/Helium" title="Helium">helium</a>. When used for <a href="/wiki/MIG_welding" title="MIG welding" class="mw-redirect">MIG welding</a>, CO<sub>2</sub> use is sometimes referred to as MAG welding, for Metal Active Gas, as CO<sub>2</sub> can react at these high temperatures. It tends to produce a hotter puddle than truly inert atmospheres, improving the flow characteristics. Although, this may be due to atmospheric reactions occurring at the puddle site. This is usually the opposite of the desired effect when welding, as it tends to embrittle the site, but may not be a problem for general mild steel welding, where ultimate ductility is not a major concern.
</p><p>It is used in many consumer products that require pressurized gas because it is inexpensive and nonflammable, and because it undergoes a phase transition from gas to liquid at room temperature at an attainable pressure of approximately 60 <a href="/wiki/Bar_(unit)" title="Bar (unit)">bar</a> (870 psi, 59 atm), allowing far more carbon dioxide to fit in a given container than otherwise would. Life jackets often contain canisters of pressured carbon dioxide for quick inflation. Aluminum capsules of CO<sub>2</sub> are also sold as supplies of compressed gas for <a href="/wiki/Air_gun" title="Air gun">airguns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paintball" title="Paintball">paintball</a> markers, inflating bicycle tires, and for making <a href="/wiki/Carbonated_water" title="Carbonated water">carbonated water</a>. Rapid vaporization of liquid carbon dioxide is used for blasting in coal mines. High concentrations of carbon dioxide can also be used to kill pests. Liquid carbon dioxide is used in <a href="/wiki/Supercritical_drying" title="Supercritical drying">supercritical drying</a> of some food products and technological materials, in the preparation of specimens for <a href="/wiki/Scanning_electron_microscopy" title="Scanning electron microscopy" class="mw-redirect">scanning electron microscopy</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/Decaffeination" title="Decaffeination">decaffeination</a> of <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a> beans.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fire_extinguisher">Fire extinguisher</span></h3>
<p>Carbon dioxide extinguishes flames, and some <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fire_extinguisher&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fire extinguisher (page does not exist)">fire extinguishers</a>, especially those designed for electrical fires, contain liquid carbon dioxide under pressure. Carbon dioxide extinguishers work well on small flammable liquid and electrical fires, but not on ordinary combustible fires, because although it excludes oxygen, it does not cool the burning substances significantly and when the carbon dioxide disperses they are free to catch fire upon exposure to atmospheric oxygen. Carbon dioxide has also been widely used as an extinguishing agent in fixed fire protection systems for local application of specific hazards and total flooding of a protected space.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> International Maritime Organization standards also recognize carbon dioxide systems for fire protection of ship holds and engine rooms. Carbon dioxide based fire protection systems have been linked to several deaths, because it can cause suffocation in sufficiently high concentrations. A review of CO<sub>2</sub> systems identified 51 incidents between 1975 and the date of the report, causing 72 deaths and 145 injuries.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Supercritical_CO2_as_solvent">Supercritical CO<sub>2</sub> as solvent</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Liquid carbon dioxide is a good <a href="/wiki/Solvent" title="Solvent">solvent</a> for many <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lipophilic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lipophilic (page does not exist)">lipophilic</a> <a href="/wiki/Organic_compound" title="Organic compound">organic compounds</a> and is used to remove <a href="/wiki/Caffeine" title="Caffeine">caffeine</a> from <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a>. Carbon dioxide has attracted attention in the <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical" title="Pharmaceutical" class="mw-redirect">pharmaceutical</a> and other chemical processing industries as a less toxic alternative to more traditional solvents such as <a href="/wiki/Organochloride" title="Organochloride">organochlorides</a>. It is used by some <a href="/wiki/Dry_cleaning" title="Dry cleaning">dry cleaners</a> for this reason (see <a href="/wiki/Green_chemistry" title="Green chemistry">green chemistry</a>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agricultural_and_biological_applications">Agricultural and biological applications</span></h3>
<p>Plants require carbon dioxide to conduct <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis">photosynthesis</a>. Greenhouses may (if of large size, must) enrich their atmospheres with additional CO<sub>2</sub> to sustain and increase plant growth.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> A photosynthesis-related drop (by a factor less than two) in carbon dioxide concentration in a greenhouse compartment would kill green plants, or, at least, completely stop their growth. At very high concentrations (100 times atmospheric concentration, or greater), carbon dioxide can be toxic to animal life, so raising the concentration to 10,000 ppm (1%) or higher for several hours will eliminate pests such as <a href="/wiki/Whitefly" title="Whitefly">whiteflies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spider_mite" title="Spider mite">spider mites</a> in a greenhouse.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> Carbon dioxide is used in greenhouses as the main carbon source for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Spirulina_(genus)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spirulina (genus) (page does not exist)">Spirulina</a></i> algae.
</p><p>In medicine, up to 5% carbon dioxide (130 times atmospheric concentration) is added to <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">oxygen</a> for stimulation of breathing after <a href="/wiki/Apnea" title="Apnea">apnea</a> and to stabilize the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> balance in blood.
</p><p>It has been proposed that carbon dioxide from power generation be bubbled into ponds to grow algae that could then be converted into <a href="/wiki/Biodiesel" title="Biodiesel">biodiesel</a> fuel.<sup id="cite_ref-csmon_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-csmon-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Oil_recovery">Oil recovery</span></h3>
<p>Carbon dioxide is used in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Enhanced_oil_recovery&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Enhanced oil recovery (page does not exist)">enhanced oil recovery</a> where it is injected into or adjacent to producing oil wells, usually under <a href="/wiki/Supercritical_fluid" title="Supercritical fluid">supercritical</a> conditions, when it becomes miscible with the oil. This approach can increase original oil recovery by reducing residual oil saturation by between 7 per cent to 23 per cent additional to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Extraction_of_petroleum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Extraction of petroleum (page does not exist)">primary extraction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> It acts as both a pressurizing agent and, when dissolved into the underground <a href="/wiki/Crude_oil" title="Crude oil" class="mw-redirect">crude oil</a>, significantly reduces its viscosity, and changing surface chemistry enabling the oil to flow more rapidly through the reservoir to the removal well.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> In mature oil fields, extensive pipe networks are used to carry the carbon dioxide to the injection points.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bio_transformation_into_fuel">Bio transformation into fuel</span></h3>
<p>Researchers have genetically modified a strain of the <a href="/wiki/Cyanobacterium" title="Cyanobacterium" class="mw-redirect">cyanobacterium</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Synechococcus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Synechococcus (page does not exist)">Synechococcus elongatus</a></i> to produce the fuels <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isobutyraldehyde&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isobutyraldehyde (page does not exist)">isobutyraldehyde</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isobutanol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isobutanol (page does not exist)">isobutanol</a> from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:CO2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:CO2 (page does not exist)">Template:CO2</a> using photosynthesis.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Refrigerant">Refrigerant</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Comparison_carbon_dioxide_water_phase_diagrams.svg" title="File:Comparison carbon dioxide water phase diagrams.svg">File:Comparison carbon dioxide water phase diagrams.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Comparison of phase diagrams of carbon dioxide (red) and water (blue) as a log-lin chart with phase transitions points at 1 atmosphere</div></div></div>
<p>Liquid and solid carbon dioxide are important <a href="/wiki/Refrigerant" title="Refrigerant">refrigerants</a>, especially in the food industry, where they are employed during the transportation and storage of ice cream and other frozen foods. Solid carbon dioxide is called "dry ice" and is used for small shipments where refrigeration equipment is not practical. Solid carbon dioxide is always below −78.5&#160;°C at regular atmospheric pressure, regardless of the air temperature.
</p><p>&lt;span id="R744" /&gt; Liquid carbon dioxide (industry nomenclature R744 or R-744) was used as a refrigerant prior to the discovery of <a href="/wiki/Dichlorodifluoromethane" title="Dichlorodifluoromethane">R-12</a> and may enjoy a renaissance due to the fact that <a href="/w/index.php?title=R134a&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="R134a (page does not exist)">R134a</a> contributes to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>. Its physical properties are highly favorable for cooling, refrigeration, and heating purposes, having a high volumetric cooling capacity. Due to its operation at pressures of up to 130 <a href="/wiki/Bar_(unit)" title="Bar (unit)">bar</a> (1880 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pounds_per_square_inch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pounds per square inch (page does not exist)">psi</a>), CO<sub>2</sub> systems require highly resistant components that have already been developed for mass production in many sectors. In automobile air conditioning, in more than 90% of all driving conditions for latitudes higher than 50°, R744 operates more efficiently than systems using R134a. Its environmental advantages (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_warming_potential&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global warming potential (page does not exist)">GWP</a> of 1, non-ozone depleting, non-toxic, non-flammable) could make it the future working fluid to replace current HFCs in cars, supermarkets, hot water heat pumps, among others. <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">Coca-Cola</a> has fielded CO<sub>2</sub>-based beverage coolers and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">U.S. Army</a> is interested in CO<sub>2</sub> refrigeration and heating technology.<sup id="cite_ref-ccref1_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ccref1-31">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-usforces_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usforces-32">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>The global automobile industry is expected to decide on the next-generation refrigerant in car air conditioning. CO<sub>2</sub> is one discussed option.(see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sustainable_automotive_air_conditioning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sustainable automotive air conditioning (page does not exist)">Sustainable automotive air conditioning</a>)
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coal_bed_methane_recovery">Coal bed methane recovery</span></h3>
<p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Enhanced_coal_bed_methane_recovery&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Enhanced coal bed methane recovery (page does not exist)">enhanced coal bed methane recovery</a>, carbon dioxide would be pumped into the coal seam to displace methane, as opposed to current methods which primarily use water to make the coal seam release its trapped methane.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Niche_uses">Niche uses</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Carbon_Dioxide_Laser_At_The_Laser_Effects_Test_Facility.jpg" title="File:Carbon Dioxide Laser At The Laser Effects Test Facility.jpg">File:Carbon Dioxide Laser At The Laser Effects Test Facility.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide_laser" title="Carbon dioxide laser">carbon dioxide laser</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Carbon dioxide is so inexpensive and so innocuous, that it finds many small uses that represent what might be called niche uses. For example it is used in the <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide_laser" title="Carbon dioxide laser">carbon dioxide laser</a>, which is one of the earliest type of lasers.
</p><p>Carbon dioxide can be used as a means of controlling the <a href="/wiki/PH" title="PH">pH</a> of swimming pools, by continuously adding gas to the water, thus keeping the pH level from rising. Among the advantages of this is the avoidance of handling (more hazardous) acids. Similarly, it is also used in the maintaining <a href="/wiki/Reef_aquarium" title="Reef aquarium">reef aquaria</a>, where it is commonly used in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Calcium_reactor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Calcium reactor (page does not exist)">calcium reactors</a> to temporarily lower the pH of water being passed over <a href="/wiki/Calcium_carbonate" title="Calcium carbonate">calcium carbonate</a> in order to allow the calcium carbonate to dissolve into the water more freely where it is used by some <a href="/wiki/Coral" title="Coral">corals</a> to build their skeleton. It is also used as the primary coolant in <a href="/wiki/Advanced_gas-cooled_reactor" title="Advanced gas-cooled reactor">advanced gas-cooled reactors</a> in the nuclear power generation industry.
</p><p>Carbon dioxide induction is commonly used for the euthanasia of laboratory research animals. Methods to administer CO<sub>2</sub> include placing animals directly into a closed, prefilled chamber containing CO<sub>2</sub>, or exposure to a gradually increasing concentration of CO<sub>2</sub>. In 2013, the <a href="/wiki/American_Veterinary_Medical_Association" title="American Veterinary Medical Association">American Veterinary Medical Association</a> issued new guidelines for carbon dioxide induction, stating that a flow rate of 10% to 30% volume/min is optimal for the humane euthanization of small rodents.<sup id="cite_ref-2013_AVMA_Guidelines_for_the_Euthanasia_of_Animals:_2013_Edition_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2013_AVMA_Guidelines_for_the_Euthanasia_of_Animals:_2013_Edition-34">[34]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_the_Earth.27s_atmosphere">In the Earth's atmosphere</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mauna_Loa_Carbon_Dioxide_Apr2013.svg" title="File:Mauna Loa Carbon Dioxide Apr2013.svg">File:Mauna Loa Carbon Dioxide Apr2013.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Keeling_Curve" title="Keeling Curve">Keeling Curve</a> of atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations measured at <a href="/wiki/Mauna_Loa_Observatory" title="Mauna Loa Observatory">Mauna Loa Observatory</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Carbon dioxide in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Earth%27s_atmosphere&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Earth's atmosphere (page does not exist)">Earth's atmosphere</a> is considered a <a href="/wiki/Trace_gas" title="Trace gas">trace gas</a> currently occurring at an average concentration of about 400 parts per million by volume<sup id="cite_ref-NOAA_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA-1">[1]</a></sup> (or 591 parts per million by mass). The total mass of atmospheric carbon dioxide is 3.16×10<sup>15</sup> kg (about 3,000 gigatonnes).{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Its concentration varies seasonally (see graph at right) and also considerably on a regional basis, especially <a href="/wiki/Planetary_boundary_layer" title="Planetary boundary layer">near the ground</a>. In urban areas concentrations are generally higher and indoors they can reach 10 times background levels. Carbon dioxide is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CO2_increase_rate.png" title="File:CO2 increase rate.png">File:CO2 increase rate.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Yearly increase of atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub>: In the 1960s, the average annual increase was 37% of the 2000–2007 average.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbon_dioxide_in_the_Earth%27s_atmosphere&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere (page does not exist)">carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere</a> is at a concentration of approximately 390 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parts_per_million&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parts per million (page does not exist)">ppm</a> by <a href="/wiki/Volume" title="Volume">volume</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> Atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide fluctuate slightly with the change of the seasons, driven primarily by seasonal plant growth in the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Hemisphere" title="Northern Hemisphere">Northern Hemisphere</a>. Concentrations of carbon dioxide fall during the northern spring and summer as plants consume the gas, and rise during the northern autumn and winter as plants go dormant, die and decay. Taking all this into account, the concentration of CO<sub>2</sub> grew by about 2 ppm in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>  "The main cause of the current global warming trend is human expansion of the "greenhouse effect"warming that results when the atmosphere traps heat radiating from Earth toward space."<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas as it is transparent to <a href="/wiki/Visible_spectrum" title="Visible spectrum">visible light</a> but absorbs strongly in the <a href="/wiki/Infrared" title="Infrared">infrared</a> and <a href="/wiki/Near-infrared" title="Near-infrared" class="mw-redirect">near-infrared</a>, before slowly re-emitting the infrared at the same wavelength as what was absorbed.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the advent of human-caused release of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere, concentrations tended to increase with increasing global temperatures, acting as a <a href="/wiki/Positive_feedback" title="Positive feedback">positive feedback</a> for changes induced by other processes such as <a href="/wiki/Milankovitch_cycles" title="Milankovitch cycles">orbital cycles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> There is a seasonal cycle in CO<sub>2</sub> concentration associated primarily with the Northern Hemisphere growing season.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>Five hundred million years ago carbon dioxide was 20 times more prevalent than today, decreasing to 4–5 times during the <a href="/wiki/Jurassic" title="Jurassic">Jurassic</a> period and then slowly declining with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Azolla_Event&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Azolla Event (page does not exist)">a particularly swift reduction</a> occurring 49 million years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Human activities such as the combustion of <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuels" title="Fossil fuels" class="mw-redirect">fossil fuels</a> and <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">deforestation</a> have caused the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide to increase by about 35% since the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">age of industrialization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-nonanews_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nonanews-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>Up to 40% of the gas emitted by some <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcanoes</a> during <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subaerial_eruption&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subaerial eruption (page does not exist)">subaerial eruptions</a> is carbon dioxide.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> It is estimated that volcanoes release about 130–230 million tonnes (145–255 million <a href="/wiki/Short_tons" title="Short tons" class="mw-redirect">short tons</a>) of CO<sub>2</sub> into the atmosphere each year. Carbon dioxide is also produced by hot springs such as those at the Bossoleto site near <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rapolano_Terme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rapolano Terme (page does not exist)">Rapolano Terme</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tuscany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tuscany (page does not exist)">Tuscany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>. Here, in a bowl-shaped depression of about 100 m diameter, local concentrations of CO<sub>2</sub> rise to above 75% overnight, sufficient to kill insects and small animals, but it warms rapidly when sunlit and the gas is dispersed by convection during the day.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> Locally high concentrations of CO<sub>2</sub>, produced by disturbance of deep lake water saturated with CO<sub>2</sub> are thought to have caused 37 fatalities at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lake_Monoun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lake Monoun (page does not exist)">Lake Monoun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cameroon" title="Cameroon">Cameroon</a> in 1984 and 1700 casualties at <a href="/wiki/Lake_Nyos" title="Lake Nyos">Lake Nyos</a>, Cameroon in 1986.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> Emissions of CO<sub>2</sub> by human activities are estimated to be 135 times greater than the quantity emitted by volcanoes.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cement" title="Cement">cement</a> industry is one of the three primary producers of carbon dioxide along with the energy production and transportation industries. As of 2011 concrete contributes 7% to global anthropogenic CO<sub>2</sub> emissions.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="In_the_oceans">In the oceans</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Carbon dioxide dissolves in the ocean to form <a href="/wiki/Carbonic_acid" title="Carbonic acid">carbonic acid</a> (H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>), <a href="/wiki/Bicarbonate" title="Bicarbonate">bicarbonate</a> (HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>−</sup>) and <a href="/wiki/Carbonate" title="Carbonate">carbonate</a> (CO<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup>), and there is about fifty times as much carbon dissolved in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sea_water&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sea water (page does not exist)">sea water</a> of the oceans as exists in the atmosphere. The oceans act as an enormous <a href="/wiki/Carbon_sink" title="Carbon sink">carbon sink</a>, and have taken up about a third of CO<sub>2</sub> emitted by human activity.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>As the concentration of carbon dioxide increases in the atmosphere, the increased uptake of carbon dioxide into the oceans is causing a measurable decrease in the pH of the oceans which is referred to as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ocean_acidification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ocean acidification (page does not exist)">ocean acidification</a>. Although the [[solubility pump|natural absorption of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>]] by the world's oceans helps mitigate the <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climatic</a> effects of anthropogenic emissions of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>, it also results in a decrease in the pH of the oceans. This reduction in pH impacts the biological systems in the oceans, primarily oceanic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Calcification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Calcification (page does not exist)">calcifying</a> organisms. These impacts span the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_chain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food chain (page does not exist)">food chain</a> from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Autotroph&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Autotroph (page does not exist)">autotrophs</a> to <a href="/wiki/Heterotroph" title="Heterotroph">heterotrophs</a> and include organisms such as <a href="/wiki/Coccolithophore" title="Coccolithophore">coccolithophores</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coral" title="Coral">corals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Foraminifera" title="Foraminifera">foraminifera</a>, <a href="/wiki/Echinoderm" title="Echinoderm">echinoderms</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crustacea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crustacea (page does not exist)">crustaceans</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mollusca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mollusca (page does not exist)">molluscs</a>. Under normal conditions, calcite and aragonite are stable in surface waters since the carbonate ion is at <a href="/wiki/Supersaturation" title="Supersaturation">supersaturating</a> concentrations. However, as ocean pH falls, so does the concentration of this ion, and when carbonate becomes undersaturated, structures made of calcium carbonate are vulnerable to dissolution. Even if there is no change in the rate of calcification, therefore, the rate of dissolution of calcareous material increases.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>Research has already found that corals,<sup id="cite_ref-gatt98_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gatt98-52">[52]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-gatt99_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gatt99-53">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lan05_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lan05-54">[54]</a></sup> coccolithophore algae,<sup id="cite_ref-rieb00_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rieb00-55">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-zond01_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zond01-56">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-zond02_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zond02-57">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-delille05_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-delille05-58">[58]</a></sup> coralline algae,<sup id="cite_ref-kuffner_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kuffner-59">[59]</a></sup> foraminifera,<sup id="cite_ref-catalyst-2007-09-13-OAtbgws_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-catalyst-2007-09-13-OAtbgws-60">[60]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shellfish" title="Shellfish">shellfish</a><sup id="cite_ref-gaz07_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gaz07-61">[61]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pteropod&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pteropod (page does not exist)">pteropods</a><sup id="cite_ref-comeau09_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-comeau09-62">[62]</a></sup> experience reduced calcification or enhanced dissolution when exposed to elevated <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>.
</p><p>Gas solubility decreases as the temperature of water increases (except when both pressure exceeds 300 bar and temperature exceeds 393 K, only found near deep geothermal vents)<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> and therefore the rate of uptake from the atmosphere decreases as ocean temperatures rise.
</p><p>Most of the CO<sub>2</sub> taken up by the ocean, which is about 30% of the total released into the atmosphere,<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> forms carbonic acid in equilibrium with bicarbonate. Some of these chemical species are consumed by photosynthestic organisms, that remove carbon from the cycle. Increased CO<sub>2</sub> in the atmosphere has led to decreasing <a href="/wiki/Alkalinity" title="Alkalinity">alkalinity</a> of seawater, and there is concern that this may adversely affect organisms living in the water. In particular, with decreasing alkalinity, the availability of carbonates for forming shells decreases,<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> although there's evidence of increased shell production by certain species under increased CO<sub>2</sub> content.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>NOAA states in their May 2008 "State of the science fact sheet for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ocean_acidification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ocean acidification (page does not exist)">ocean acidification</a>" that:<br />
"The oceans have absorbed about 50% of the carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) released from the burning of fossil fuels, resulting in chemical reactions that lower ocean pH. This has caused an increase in hydrogen ion (acidity) of about 30% since the start of the industrial age through a process known as "ocean acidification." A growing number of studies have demonstrated adverse impacts on marine organisms, including:
</p>
<ul>
<li> The rate at which reef-building corals produce their skeletons decreases, while production of numerous varieties of jellyfish increases.
</li>
<li> The ability of marine algae and free-swimming zooplankton to maintain protective shells is reduced.
</li>
<li> The survival of larval marine species, including commercial fish and shellfish, is reduced."
</li>
</ul>
<p>Also, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) writes in their Climate Change 2007: Synthesis Report:<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> <br />
"The uptake of anthropogenic carbon since 1750 has led to the ocean becoming more acidic with an average decrease in pH of 0.1 units. Increasing atmospheric CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations lead to further acidification&#160;... While the effects of observed ocean acidification on the marine biosphere are as yet undocumented, the progressive acidification of oceans is expected to have negative impacts on marine shell-forming organisms (e.g. corals) and their dependent species."
</p><p>Some marine calcifying organisms (including coral reefs) have been singled out by major research agencies, including NOAA, OSPAR commission, NANOOS and the IPCC, because their most current research shows that ocean acidification should be expected to impact them negatively.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>Carbon dioxide is also introduced into the oceans through hydrothermal vents. The <i>Champagne</i> hydrothermal vent, found at the Northwest Eifuku volcano at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marianas_Trench_Marine_National_Monument&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marianas Trench Marine National Monument (page does not exist)">Marianas Trench Marine National Monument</a>, produces almost pure liquid carbon dioxide, one of only two known sites in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Sea_urchin" title="Sea urchin">Sea urchins</a> have been discovered to be able to convert carbon dioxide into raw material for their shells.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biological_role">Biological role</span></h2>
<p>Carbon dioxide is an end product in organisms that obtain energy from breaking down sugars, fats and <a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">amino acids</a> with <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">oxygen</a> as part of their <a href="/wiki/Metabolism" title="Metabolism">metabolism</a>, in a process known as <a href="/wiki/Cellular_respiration" title="Cellular respiration">cellular respiration</a>. This includes all plants, animals, many fungi and some bacteria. In higher animals, the carbon dioxide travels in the blood from the body's tissues to the lungs where it is exhaled. In plants using photosynthesis, carbon dioxide is absorbed from the atmosphere.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Photosynthesis_and_carbon_fixation">Photosynthesis and carbon fixation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Auto-and_heterotrophs.png" title="File:Auto-and heterotrophs.png">File:Auto-and heterotrophs.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Overview of photosynthesis and respiration. Carbon dioxide (at right), together with water, form oxygen and organic compounds (at left) by <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis"><span style="color:green;">photosynthesis</span></a>, which can be <a href="/wiki/Cellular_respiration" title="Cellular respiration"><span style="color:red;">respired</span></a> to water and (CO<sub>2</sub>).</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Calvin-cycle4.svg" title="File:Calvin-cycle4.svg">File:Calvin-cycle4.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><b>Figure 2</b>. Overview of the <a href="/wiki/Calvin_cycle" title="Calvin cycle" class="mw-redirect">Calvin cycle</a> and carbon fixation</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Carbon_fixation" title="Carbon fixation">Carbon fixation</a> is the removal of carbon dioxide from the air and its incorporation into solid compounds. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plant (page does not exist)">Plants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">algae</a>, and many species of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacteria (page does not exist)">bacteria</a> (<a href="/wiki/Cyanobacteria" title="Cyanobacteria">cyanobacteria</a>) fix carbon and create their own food by <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis">photosynthesis</a>. Photosynthesis uses carbon dioxide and <a href="/wiki/Water" title="Water">water</a> to produce <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugars</a> and occasionally other <a href="/wiki/Organic_compound" title="Organic compound">organic compounds</a>, releasing <a href="/wiki/Oxygen" title="Oxygen">oxygen</a> as a waste product.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/RuBisCO" title="RuBisCO">Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase oxygenase</a>, commonly known by the shorter name RuBisCO, is an <a href="/wiki/Enzyme" title="Enzyme">enzyme</a> involved in the first major step of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_fixation" title="Carbon fixation">carbon fixation</a>, a process by which atmospheric carbon dioxide is converted by plants to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fuel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fuel (page does not exist)">energy-rich</a> <a href="/wiki/Molecule" title="Molecule">molecules</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a>. It is also thought to be the single most abundant protein on Earth.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>These <a href="/wiki/Phototroph" title="Phototroph">phototrophs</a> use the products of their photosynthesis as internal food sources and as raw material for the construction of more complex organic molecules, such as <a href="/wiki/Polysaccharides" title="Polysaccharides" class="mw-redirect">polysaccharides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nucleic_acid" title="Nucleic acid">nucleic acids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">proteins</a>. These are used for their own growth, and also as the basis for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_chain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food chain (page does not exist)">food chains</a> and webs whereby other organisms, including animals such as ourselves, are fed.
