Some important phototrophs, the <a href="/wiki/Coccolithophore" title="Coccolithophore">coccolithophores</a> synthesise hard <a href="/wiki/Calcium_carbonate" title="Calcium carbonate">calcium carbonate</a> scales. A globally significant species of coccolithophore is <i><a href="/wiki/Emiliania_huxleyi" title="Emiliania huxleyi">Emiliania huxleyi</a></i> whose <a href="/wiki/Calcite" title="Calcite">calcite</a> scales have formed the basis of many <a href="/wiki/Sedimentary_rock" title="Sedimentary rock">sedimentary rocks</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a>, where what was previously atmospheric carbon can remain fixed for geological timescales.
</p><p>Plants can grow up to 50 percent faster in concentrations of 1,000 ppm CO<sub>2</sub> when compared with ambient conditions, though this assumes no change in climate and no limitation on other nutrients.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> Research has shown that elevated CO<sub>2</sub> levels cause increased growth reflected in the harvestable yield of crops, with wheat, rice and soybean all showing increases in yield of 12–14% under elevated CO<sub>2</sub> in FACE experiments.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p>Studies have shown that increased CO<sub>2</sub> leads to fewer stomata developing on plants<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> which leads to reduced water usage.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> Studies using <a href="/w/index.php?title=Free-Air_Concentration_Enrichment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Free-Air Concentration Enrichment (page does not exist)">FACE</a> have shown that increases in CO<sub>2</sub> lead to decreased concentration of micronutrients in crop plants.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> This may have knock-on effects on other parts of <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystems</a> as herbivores will need to eat more food to gain the same amount of protein.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>The concentration of secondary <a href="/wiki/Metabolites" title="Metabolites" class="mw-redirect">metabolites</a> such as phenylpropanoids and flavonoids
can also be altered in plants exposed to high concentrations of CO<sub>2</sub>.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Plants also emit CO<sub>2</sub> during respiration, and so the majority of plants and algae, which use <a href="/w/index.php?title=C3_photosynthesis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C3 photosynthesis (page does not exist)">C3 photosynthesis</a>, are only net absorbers during the day. Though a growing forest will absorb many tons of CO<sub>2</sub> each year, the World Bank writes that a mature forest will produce as much CO<sub>2</sub> from respiration and decomposition of dead specimens (e.g., fallen branches) as is used in <a href="/wiki/Biosynthesis" title="Biosynthesis">biosynthesis</a> in growing plants.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> However six experts in biochemistry, biogeology, forestry and related areas writing in the science journal Nature that "Our results demonstrate that old-growth forests can continue to accumulate carbon, contrary to the long-standing view that they are carbon neutral."<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> Mature forests are valuable <a href="/wiki/Carbon_sink" title="Carbon sink">carbon sinks</a>, helping maintain balance in the Earth's atmosphere. Additionally, and crucially to life on earth, photosynthesis by phytoplankton consumes dissolved CO<sub>2</sub> in the upper ocean and thereby promotes the absorption of CO<sub>2</sub> from the atmosphere.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Toxicity">Toxicity</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Main_symptoms_of_carbon_dioxide_toxicity.svg" title="File:Main symptoms of carbon dioxide toxicity.svg">File:Main symptoms of carbon dioxide toxicity.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Main symptoms of carbon dioxide toxicity, by increasing <a href="/wiki/Volume_percent" title="Volume percent">volume percent</a> in air.<sup id="cite_ref-friedman_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-friedman-84">[84]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Carbon dioxide content in fresh air (averaged between sea-level and 10 kPa level, i.e., about 30&#160;km altitude) varies between 0.036% (360 ppm) and 0.039% (390 ppm), depending on the location.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>CO<sub>2</sub> is an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asphyxiant_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asphyxiant gas (page does not exist)">asphyxiant gas</a> and not classified as toxic or harmful in accordance with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Globally_Harmonized_System_of_Classification_and_Labelling_of_Chemicals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals (page does not exist)">Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals standards</a> of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Economic_Commission_for_Europe" title="United Nations Economic Commission for Europe">United Nations Economic Commission for Europe</a> by using the <a href="/w/index.php?title=OECD_Guidelines_for_the_Testing_of_Chemicals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="OECD Guidelines for the Testing of Chemicals (page does not exist)">OECD Guidelines for the Testing of Chemicals</a>. In concentrations up to 1% (10,000 ppm), it will make some people feel drowsy.<sup id="cite_ref-friedman_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-friedman-84">[84]</a></sup> Concentrations of 7% to 10% may cause suffocation, even in the presence of sufficient oxygen, manifesting as dizziness, headache, visual and hearing dysfunction, and unconsciousness within a few minutes to an hour.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because it's heavier than air, in locations where the gas seeps from the ground (due to sub-surface volcanic or geothermal activity) in relatively high levels, without the dispersing effects of wind, it can collect in sheltered/pocketed locations below average ground level, causing animals located therein to be suffocated. Carrion feeders attracted to the carcasses are then also killed. For example, children have been killed in the same way near the city of <a href="/wiki/Goma" title="Goma">Goma</a> due to nearby volcanic <a href="/wiki/Mt._Nyiragongo" title="Mt. Nyiragongo" class="mw-redirect">Mt. Nyiragongo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Swahili_language" title="Swahili language">Swahili</a> term for this phenomena is '<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mazuku&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mazuku (page does not exist)">mazuku</a>'.
</p><p>Adaptation to increased levels of CO<sub>2</sub> occurs in humans. Continuous inhalation of CO<sub>2</sub> can be tolerated at three percent inspired concentrations for at least one month and four percent inspired concentrations for over a week. It was suggested that 2.0 percent inspired concentrations could be used for closed air spaces (e.g. a <a href="/wiki/Submarine" title="Submarine">submarine</a>) since the adaptation is physiological and reversible. Decrement in performance or in normal physical activity does not happen at this level.<sup id="cite_ref-Glatte_Jr_H._A..2C_Motsay_G._J..2C_Welch_B._E._1967_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Glatte_Jr_H._A..2C_Motsay_G._J..2C_Welch_B._E._1967-88">[88]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> However, it should be noted that submarines have <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbon_dioxide_scrubber&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbon dioxide scrubber (page does not exist)">carbon dioxide scrubbers</a> which reduce a significant amount of the CO<sub>2</sub> present.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>Acute carbon dioxide physiological effect is <a href="/wiki/Hypercapnia" title="Hypercapnia">hypercapnia</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asphyxiant_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asphyxiant gas (page does not exist)">asphyxiation</a> sometimes known by the names given to it by miners: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blackdamp&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blackdamp (page does not exist)">blackdamp</a> (also called <i>choke damp</i> or <i>stythe</i>). Blackdamp is primarily nitrogen and carbon dioxide and kills via suffocation (having displaced oxygen). <a href="/wiki/Miners" title="Miners" class="mw-redirect">Miners</a> would try to alert themselves to dangerous levels of blackdamp and other gases in a mine shaft by bringing a caged <a href="/w/index.php?title=Domestic_Canary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Domestic Canary (page does not exist)">canary</a> with them as they worked. The canary is more sensitive to environmental gases than humans and as it became unconscious would stop singing and fall off its perch. The <a href="/wiki/Davy_lamp" title="Davy lamp">Davy lamp</a> could also detect high levels of blackdamp (which collect near the floor) by burning less brightly, while <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methane (page does not exist)">methane</a>, another suffocating gas and explosion risk would make the lamp burn more brightly.
</p><p>Carbon dioxide differential above outdoor levels at steady state conditions (when the occupancy and ventilation system operation are sufficiently long that CO<sub>2</sub> concentration has stabilized) are sometimes used to estimate ventilation rates per person. CO<sub>2</sub> is considered to be a surrogate for human bio-effluents and may correlate with other indoor pollutants. Higher CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations are associated with occupant health, comfort and performance degradation. <a href="/wiki/ASHRAE" title="ASHRAE">ASHRAE</a> Standard 62.1–2007 ventilation rates may result in indoor levels up to 2,100 ppm above ambient outdoor conditions. Thus if the outdoor ambient is 400 ppm, indoor levels may reach 2,500 ppm with ventilation rates that meet this industry consensus standard. Levels in poorly ventilated spaces can be found even higher than this (range of 3,000 or 4,000).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_physiology">Human physiology</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Content">Content</span></h4>
<p>The body produces approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of carbon dioxide per day per person,<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> containing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of carbon.
</p><p>{{#invoke:anchor|main}}In humans, this carbon dioxide is carried through the venous system and is breathed out through the lungs. Therefore, the carbon dioxide content in the body is high in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Venous_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Venous system (page does not exist)">venous system</a>, and decreases in the <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_system" title="Respiratory system">respiratory system</a>, resulting in lower levels along any <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arterial_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arterial system (page does not exist)">arterial system</a>. Carbon dioxide content in this sense is often given as the <a href="/wiki/Partial_pressure" title="Partial pressure">partial pressure</a>, which is the pressure which carbon dioxide would have had if it alone occupied the volume.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p><p>In humans, the carbon dioxide contents are as follows:
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<caption><a href="/wiki/Reference_range" title="Reference range">Reference ranges</a> or averages for <a href="/wiki/Partial_pressure" title="Partial pressure">partial pressures</a> of carbon dioxide (abbreviated PCO<sub>2</sub>)
</caption>
<tr>
<th> Unit </th>
<th> <a href="/wiki/Vein" title="Vein">Venous</a> blood gas  </th>
<th> Alveolar <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pulmonary_gas_pressures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pulmonary gas pressures (page does not exist)">pulmonary<br /> gas pressures</a> </th>
<th> <a href="/wiki/Arterial_blood_gas#carbon_dioxide" title="Arterial blood gas">Arterial blood carbon dioxide</a>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Kilopascal" title="Kilopascal" class="mw-redirect">kPa</a> </td>
<td> 5.5<sup id="cite_ref-mmHg_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mmHg-93">[93]</a></sup>-6.8<sup id="cite_ref-mmHg_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mmHg-93">[93]</a></sup> </td>
<td> 4.8 </td>
<td> 4.7<sup id="cite_ref-mmHg_93-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mmHg-93">[93]</a></sup>-6.0<sup id="cite_ref-mmHg_93-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mmHg-93">[93]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/MmHg" title="MmHg" class="mw-redirect">mmHg</a> </td>
<td> 41<sup id="cite_ref-brookside_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brookside-94">[94]</a></sup>-51<sup id="cite_ref-brookside_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brookside-94">[94]</a></sup> </td>
<td> 36 </td>
<td> 35<sup id="cite_ref-southwest_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-southwest-95">[95]</a></sup>-45<sup id="cite_ref-southwest_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-southwest-95">[95]</a></sup>
</td></tr></table>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport_in_the_blood">Transport in the blood</span></h4>
<p>CO<sub>2</sub> is carried in blood in three different ways. (The exact percentages vary depending whether it is arterial or venous blood).
</p>
<ul>
<li> Most of it (about 70% to 80%) is converted to <a href="/wiki/Bicarbonate" title="Bicarbonate">bicarbonate</a> ions <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a> by the enzyme <a href="/wiki/Carbonic_anhydrase" title="Carbonic anhydrase">carbonic anhydrase</a> in the red blood cells,<sup id="cite_ref-solarnav_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-solarnav-96">[96]</a></sup> by the reaction CO<sub>2</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O → H<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> → H<sup>+</sup> + <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chem (page does not exist)">Template:Chem</a>.
</li>
<li> 5% – 10% is dissolved in the <a href="/wiki/Blood_plasma" title="Blood plasma">plasma</a><sup id="cite_ref-solarnav_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-solarnav-96">[96]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> 5% – 10% is bound to <a href="/wiki/Hemoglobin" title="Hemoglobin">hemoglobin</a> as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carbamino&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carbamino (page does not exist)">carbamino</a> compounds<sup id="cite_ref-solarnav_96-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-solarnav-96">[96]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hemoglobin" title="Hemoglobin">Hemoglobin</a>, the main oxygen-carrying molecule in <a href="/wiki/Red_blood_cell" title="Red blood cell">red blood cells</a>, carries both oxygen and carbon dioxide. However, the CO<sub>2</sub> bound to hemoglobin does not bind to the same site as oxygen. Instead, it combines with the N-terminal groups on the four globin chains. However, because of <a href="/wiki/Allosteric_regulation" title="Allosteric regulation">allosteric</a> effects on the hemoglobin molecule, the binding of CO<sub>2</sub> decreases the amount of oxygen that is bound for a given partial pressure of oxygen. The decreased binding to carbon dioxide in the blood due to increased oxygen levels is known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Haldane_Effect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Haldane Effect (page does not exist)">Haldane Effect</a>, and is important in the transport of carbon dioxide from the tissues to the lungs. Conversely, a rise in the partial pressure of CO<sub>2</sub> or a lower pH will cause offloading of oxygen from hemoglobin, which is known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bohr_Effect&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bohr Effect (page does not exist)">Bohr Effect</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Regulation_of_respiration">Regulation of respiration</span></h4>
<p>Carbon dioxide is one of the mediators of local <a href="/w/index.php?title=Autoregulation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Autoregulation (page does not exist)">autoregulation</a> of blood supply. If its levels are high, the <a href="/wiki/Capillaries" title="Capillaries" class="mw-redirect">capillaries</a> expand to allow a greater blood flow to that tissue.
</p><p>Bicarbonate ions are crucial for regulating blood pH. A person's breathing rate influences the level of CO<sub>2</sub> in their blood. Breathing that is too slow or shallow causes <a href="/wiki/Respiratory_acidosis" title="Respiratory acidosis">respiratory acidosis</a>, while breathing that is too rapid leads to <a href="/wiki/Hyperventilation" title="Hyperventilation">hyperventilation</a>, which can cause <a href="/wiki/Alkalosis" title="Alkalosis">respiratory alkalosis</a>.
</p><p>Although the body requires oxygen for metabolism, low oxygen levels normally do not stimulate breathing. Rather, breathing is stimulated by higher carbon dioxide levels. As a result, breathing low-pressure air or a gas mixture with no oxygen at all (such as pure nitrogen) can lead to loss of consciousness without ever experiencing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Air_hunger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Air hunger (page does not exist)">air hunger</a>. This is especially perilous for high-altitude fighter pilots. It is also why flight attendants instruct passengers, in case of loss of cabin pressure, to apply the <a href="/wiki/Oxygen_mask" title="Oxygen mask">oxygen mask</a> to themselves first before helping others; otherwise, one risks losing consciousness.<sup id="cite_ref-solarnav_96-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-solarnav-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>The respiratory centers try to maintain an arterial CO<sub>2</sub> pressure of 40&#160;mm Hg. With intentional hyperventilation, the CO<sub>2</sub> content of arterial blood may be lowered to 10–20&#160;mm Hg (the oxygen content of the blood is little affected), and the respiratory drive is diminished. This is why one can hold one's breath longer after hyperventilating than without hyperventilating. This carries the risk that unconsciousness may result before the need to breathe becomes overwhelming, which is why hyperventilation is particularly dangerous before free diving.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tyler_Volk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tyler Volk (page does not exist)">Tyler Volk</a> (2008), <i>CO<sub>2</sub> Rising: The World's Greatest Environmental Challenge</i>, The MIT Press, 223 pages, <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780262220835" class="internal mw-magiclink-isbn">ISBN 978-0-262-22083-5</a>. A short, balanced primer on CO<sub>2</sub>'s role as a greenhouse gas. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ehponline.org/docs/2009/117-2/newbooks.html">Review</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Dead_link&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Dead link (page does not exist)">Template:Dead link</a> at <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_Health_Perspectives&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental Health Perspectives (page does not exist)">Environmental Health Perspectives</a></i>
</li>
<li> Shendell, Prill, Fisk, Apte1, Blake &amp; Faulkner, Associations between classroom CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations and student attendance in Washington and Idaho, Indoor Air 2004.
</li>
<li> Seppanen, Fisk and Mendell, Association of Ventilation Rates and CO<sub>2</sub> Concentrations with Health and Other Responses in Commercial and Institutional Buildings, Indoor Air 1999.
</li>
</ul>

</li>
